message.content:
cs.GT, cs.NE, cs.DS, cs.LG, cs.IT. 

This paper deals with game theory and optimization problems related to network routing and job-shop scheduling, which are typically studied in the sub-categories of cs.GT (game theory), cs.NE (network economics), cs.DS (data structures and algorithms), cs.LG (machine learning), and cs.IT (information theory). The paper specifically focuses on bottleneck congestion games, which are a well-studied class of games in the field of network economics and are closely related to routing problems. The introduction of polynomial bottleneck games is a novel contribution to the field, and the paper provides tight bounds on the price of anarchy for these games using transformation and expansion techniques, which are commonly used in the sub-categories of cs.DS and cs.LG. Overall, the paper's content and methodology suggest that it is most likely to belong to the cs.GT, cs.NE, cs.DS, cs.LG, or cs.IT sub-categories.
